I played it 3 or 4 times and I came to the conclusion that I detest this game. I'm not saying it's not good, but for my taste... it's just a nightmare.

My hatred against this boils down to: in my opinion the rules, the scoring... the game makes no sense.
How?
Well, the rules:
- Coal needs connection. Check.
- Beer needs connection, unless it's yours because then it warps. Oooookay?
- Iron, always warps. What?

The game:
You're trying to be a successful businessman during the industrial revolution by handing over your resources to just anyone... for free. Because after your mine runs out it starts to produce revenue. Because that's what it does!
You can also get successful by building connections between the cities aka. you can have a transportation business. Sounds good! It pays absolutely nothing and only gives victory points at the end of the eras, but it can give half your points! So during the game it's almost entirely useless and you build most of it out of necessity but it's a huge factor in your success. Makes sense? Not for me.

And what absolutely doesn't influence your success is how much money you make from round to round... because money plays absolutely no role in business, right?!

Btw, it's not a strategy game. The biggest strategy you have to "build" is when not to spend money. Other than that it's mostly opportunitism and making the most out of the random cards you draw. It's not bad, I just do not understand how is it the no.1 strategy game without any strategy. :/

Oh, and the interaction between the players is not positive. Everyone gonna try to take their opponents resources in a way that it is the least beneficial for their opponent. The one taking the resource is not interested in emptying the tile while just getting rid of 1 resorce gives nothing for the owner. It is more like passive agressive.

In short: the game is illogical and the lack of agency over your resources annoys me so much that if I never see this game again even that will be too soon.

Brass has been on top of the game lists for a while now. I've always had a particular interest to try the game, and finally got my chance. And I was very disappointed.

It doesn't start well if I need to put on my glasses to read the board, my own player board and the cards. But, in the end it is about gameplay so I could forgive that.

What I can't forgive is the poor theming. It just does not fit the gameplay. Brass should be about making money. But here is seems that lending money is the better way. In essence, Brass a game where a certain theme is slapped onto a generic "construct buildings and boats/trains" boardgame, with no depth whatsoever.

Then... I played the game... and won... by having zero interaction with fellow players. My table mates were also flabbergasted that it worked out this way, as the game insinuates advantages if people use your items.

Also the game is very card dependent. You need some luck to get the right cards and if the location cards are too spread over the board or you have too many different product cards, it just doesn't work well for you and you are just filling a seat at the table.

And the game takes way too long. Waiting, waiting, waiting. It is so boring as nothing happens.

Someone looked at the original Brass, didn't notice how it's much better than the vast majority of games released in the past ten years, and set out trying to make it more 2018 and therefore, a pale shadow of the original.

I quite like the more generous implementation of "playing wild" (getting the Wild Location & Industry cards, vs. just making a single wild move) and it has been done in an inventive and interesting way, however it works toward the overall objective of filing away "rough edges", or as they're also known, interesting parts of the design.

All elements of "co-opetition", where players could work together in certain domains to further them both, have been stripped away in the name of an efficiency exercise where each player runs their individual business empire and tries to shut out the others. It's perhaps more competitive than some contemporary designs but it plays almost as if someone read the rulebook of Brass but never played it.

Worst of all, this new version has inspired some insipid play of the original where players go out of their way not to interact with others and lean away from some of the interesting specialisation and cooperation that is the way to score highly in Brass, or as we are apparently now forced to call it, "Brass Lancashire". (No doubt I should anticipate a visit from a modern-Euro bailiff that tries to force entry to my home to write "Lancashire" on my box with a permanent marker.)

Brass Birmingham felt very tactical to me. It's a mishmash of elements (board resets, hand management, non-engine building, weak interaction, unintuitive transport mechanisms) that--at best--I am lukewarm on. Overall, it was just a wholly uncompelling package, absolutely overhyped, and left me with a disappointing feeling of ennui.

If I'm going to play a game with shared infrastructure, I'd much prefer Sol: Last Days of a Star or The Great Zimbabwe.

The rules are not just abstract but counter-intuitive: why connection to my network is needed for consumption of coal but not for iron? Why players can gain more income and points when all coal on a coal mine are used up? Shouldn't a coal mine generate coal for use every turn? Why players can consume other players' resources without paying while they are required to pay when buying from the market? What is the point of the cards when only 1 out of the 6 possible actions is related to the card discarded? Why sometimes I can build using other players' canal but sometimes I can't? There are more but what I want to point out is that the theme is just completely irrelevant to the game. I don't see how this game is fun and I would prefer more simple, yet comprehensible economic game over Brass.

This game is not about deciding what to do. It's about figuring out what you can do by navigating the silly amount of clunky exceptions slowly but surely chipping away your decision space until only 1-2 options are remaining. Turns take a long time not because of strategy, but because of how fiddly everything is. The rules are nonsensical from a logic standpoint. Some resources follow networks, some teleport, some do both, sometimes, except x and y and z. And then, halfway through the game, the connections between the places you worked on for the last hour and a half have to be removed and redone from scratch in the second half. The graphic design is abysmal, symbols are lost in the unnecessary detail, everything becomes a blurry mess, while important information is hidden away in the corners. The player aids that come in the box are worthless, the game is genuinely unlearnable and unplayable without the user-made ones. Furthermore, the setup and the mid-game scoring/upkeep are tedious, fiddly and take way too long. This game does not deserve the praise it gets, at all.

Pros: tight mechanics once you know how to use them, satisfying systems, wide decision space.

Cons: dingey look to the board, inconsistent or idiosyncratic rules (why can iron be used anywhere but coal needs to be connected to be consumed?), theme and gameplay are not well linked (see last example), fiddly with too many components, boring theme, the inability to plan ahead due to the constantly changing board state makes players' turns take too long.

Overly complex, fiddly, and boring. I really don't get the hype with this.

Loosens some of Lancashire's annoyingly tight bolts: the Scout action is vastly better than the double discard, the variable setup adds some spice, and the splintering of cotton into different sub-industries gives a little more creative freedom to players.

Much of Brass's trademark interdependency is now carried out through beer, as it is required to flip pretty much every other building type. It's a decent replacement for Lancashire's ports, other than the supremely silly rule that your own beer can be teleported across the map without using links, which leads to very un-Brass-like plays of exploiting your own isolated, untouchable resource supply rather than forcing entanglement with a common stock.

Despite this uninterractive blunder, I do appreciate that beer attaches a much-needed brake pedal to link development in the rail era, as it's now a resource requirement for the double build action. Unfortunately, and despite this bottleneck, Birmingham is still stricken with Brass's unforgiveable curse: links are still boring and they're still way too efficient for how unilateral and unimaginative of a point source they are. I was excited when I heard that Birmingham had industries that provide variable link points, as I assumed that meant the overall point density would go down. Insanely, it's the exact opposite: certain key locations on the map can now be (and often are) stacked with multiple 2-point tiles, and links make up even more of your score. Ugh.

The original Brass is a game I consider almost-great. To see the best (and possibly only) attempt at remastering it fail to reach this potential is a terrible, painful waste.

- With an absurd amount of exceptions in the rules making the game complicated and very fiddley to play.
- The game gives you analysis paralysis not because there are many options to explore, but because it takes a very long time to realize how little options you have.
- Because of all that, the game takes much longer to play than it should.
- The game offers very little freedom, everybody is symmetrical and play the exact same game from start to finish, you have no freedom to choose your own playstyle you just do whatever you can given your cards and the board set up.
- This also means that the game has very low replayability, after playing one game you've seen everything the game has to offer and there is not much content/strategy to explore.

On the positive side the game has some very satisfying moments alongside a couple of interesting mechanism but so do MANY other euro games that are far more enjoyable to play and don't have the flaws written above.

I purchased this game because of its #1 status, and because of how much I enjoyed Radlands (same publisher).

With the good out of the way, key red flags that made me give this game away after only playing twice:
1) There is no reasonable way to track score till the end - there is a point tracker, but there are so many points scored at the end, you can't tell if your strategy is putting you in the lead or not.
2) While scoring, if someone accidentally moves the wrong tracker token, there is no way to figure out the mistake - since there are so many steps to scoring its easy to mess up the board
3) the board has so many pieces, if the table gets jostled, its hard to place all the pieces back since the board has no recessed troughs for pieces (we have a 300lb game table, and this was still a problem).
4) there is a defined mechanic to discard one card from the deck per player (this starts each players discard pile). However, while this is stated as required and makes the turns even out, this is incorrect - it leads to half of the players getting 1 extra turn in the first half and half of the players getting 1 extra turn in the second half. Depending on how the game plays out, the same group of people may get both extra turns. By simply ignoring this rule, the turn counts even out.

Full transparency: I like pure strategy, no luck and clear tracking of progress. Perhaps this game just isnt for me, but it seems to have serious design flaws. I am at a loss for why this is sitting at #1, even more confused as to how it got there.

I personally struggle to see why it’s considered a #1 on BGG, even for people who enjoy these strategic traits, there must be something missing.

What I really miss is a sense of achievement or progress. There are indicators, but they’re mostly numbers, nothing that feels satisfying or sparks joy. Some rules feel like “patches” added to fit the theme, such as the canal and rail periods, which add complexity without much payoff. Thematically, I also feel disconnected: I never get the sense that I’m truly building something meaningful. I’m placing industries purely for resources or points. While efficiency is common in many games, a strong theme usually gives you additional satisfaction for why you’re building, which Brass largely misses.

All things considered, I could play it again, but it won’t spark joy.

Having now experimented thousands of boardgames, I came to the conclusion that Brass Birmingham is mediocre at its best. It's far from being the best from Wallace; it's even further than being the best game of the world. I understand how people are really attached to this game, since it checks all the boxes modern euro amateurs would want in a game.

Brass: Birmingham limits player interaction from its predecessor, which leads more often than not to a multiplayer solitaire experience. Granted, there is some interaction, and there are other games much more prone to falling into this trap (hi Ark Nova!), but there are not enough ways to sustain mid or long-term conflicts between players. It is immediate and blend: someone took your spot, or your beer, or screwed your short-term planning. After 2 or 3 rounds, you went past it and are now on to something else.

Overall, I appreciate to play Birmingham as an activity and to please fellow gamers, but as a game, this has nothing that stands out to me. Mediocre mechanisms that lead to low-level player interaction. And the leaves a sugar-free shortbread cookie taste in my mouth when I'm done playing it.

In this game, interaction emerges from mastery of quite fiddly rules. So for me, as a beginner player, it still feels like I need to game the system, and not the other players. So while Brass offers much fundamentally different and more interaction than comparable games in its genre, I still felt like I was playing an efficiency puzzle. And I got crushed under the weight of my misplays.

03.2023

GAMEPLAY
On a turn, a player plays two cards from hand, taking an action with each card. Actions include take loans, build links, develop industries, build industries, sell goods, scout (i.e., get wild cards), and pass. VPs are scored by 1) building industries and then flipping them to their profitable side, either by consuming their resources or selling the goods they produce; and 2) link VP scored by connecting two cities or a city and offboard area. Birmingham takes place over two eras, the canal era and rail era, and the game ends when players play all their cards in the rail era.

THOUGHTS
I was excited by the idea of Brass becoming a “system” game, similar to Age of Steam or Power Grid where different maps make slight tweaks on a very interesting foundation. And while I’m still excited by the possibilities, Birmingham is most definitely NOT for me as it revels in all the worst, modern Euro impulses. To wit, when compared with Lancashire, it’s longer, it’s more complicated, and—most damning of all—it’s softer.

The complicated side. Although I tried to make excuses for beer, it’s a pain in the ass to teach, not to mention the constant reminders and rules questions that come up regarding it’s consumption and use. Add to this all the faffing with offboard areas and the merchant tiles and bonuses, and I often feel like I spend more time helping players internalize the rules than enjoying the game play.

The soft side. The scout action, while I think it’s evidence of a suboptimal move, provides an unnecessary flexibility. Also eased are the restrictions on taking late-game loans. But the worst offender in this category are the coal and iron markets that make it nearly impossible to ever overbuild an opponent.

All this said, I actively dislike Birmingham because why put all that time and effort in when I’d only be playing a facsimile of a good game.

This game takes the exemplary qualities of Brass and paints over them with a Euro brush. To me, Brass is about opportunity and interdependence. This game takes focus away from other players over to one's own board. Even though this game is using the Brass system, the times I'd choose to play this game isn't when I'd want to play Brass, but when I'm in the mood for something like Terraforming Mars or Lisboa (which is never).
I love what you do on the board, but I hate the cards, which could have been removed in this new edition. But it wasn't at that irks me...

The corners have been padded in comparison its predecessor, far less aggressively competitive than the original due to the new resource constraints and the diversity of industry to choose from. What results is less of a knives-out fight for territory and more of a balance of parallel competitive interests (so: less interdependent).

Breweries are too good. They score well AND they have good income AND all players need beer for just about any meaningful action they want to take. Breweries are a terrible replacement for Ports, which were the crux of the interdependent incentive structure in Lancashire. Moreover, the rules for beer consumption are bordering on nonsensical.

The economy is much looser, and the opportunity cost for the Scout action is virtually zero compared to the real tension around the double action build requirements in the original.

There are far too many multi-industry spaces. Sure choices are wide and varied, but it's far less important what your opponents are doing.

I also dislike the rule that you're allowed to build a link before you build any industry. It removes most of the timing considerations around who gets down the first Ironworks.

Basically, Birmingham has sacrificed competitive interdependencies and the beauty of a player-created supply/demand system for the tragically modern design aesthetics of "setup variability" (which the game didn't need) and "multiple paths to victory," which is euro-design speak for "I'm more interested in beating a gaming system than my opponents."

Birmingham doesn't completely lack interdependencies/interaction, but there are far fewer here than in the original game.

How to take few of the mechanics of Ticket to Ride to make a great economic game.

The gameplay is simple yet hard to master (6 actions). You have to build factories to produce ore (coal/iron) and goods to sell.

Few things :

- you can build in your network (connected by factories or boats/trains) with production cards or use city-cards
- cards are randomly draw but bad luck can be mitigated by taking one action for drawing "jokers"
- building factory is half the job as selling ore or goods are requires to get the victory points and income bonus. Therefore one of the biggest strategy is to minimize the time of "dead assets" and selling as fast as possible
- the is almost no way to get instant money, instead selling ore/goods increase slowy your income rate. However you can take one action to make juicy loan and reduce your income.

OKAY, so why so bad review (5) ?

Because I found that this game as almost no long-term strategy. It is mostly instant reaction to the current situation (what card in my hand, what can I do NOW to maximize income/VP). The reason is because you have to sell everything FAST.

Exemple :
- the coal ore market is tight. It will be very JUICY to build a coal mine NOW. If you can't, you'll miss a ONE time opportunity because someone else will build this coal mine. Did you do something to influence the market ? No. Did you control if you have a mine card right now ? Probably not (you have to draw a joker which is one action less for more important things).

It is just of example of the numerous situations in which long term planning just don't work. And I find it very unsatisfying because the game somehow make luck and situation have more importance than strategy.

I would love this game if it could completely remove the random elements. Clearly, drawing card may have been a sufficient mechanic for family game as Ticket to Ride but it is a poor mechanic for advanced strategy game.

Finally got this to the table after almost a dozen plays of Lancashire.

Birmingham is much fiddlier. Much more difficult to put together a sequence of useful actions. The addition of beer, and the wonky benefits of manufactured goods and pottery, make for a more uneven and frustrating experience all around. That’s not sour grapes - I won handily.

Presumably, Birmingham is intended to refresh the challenge for people who have played out Lancashire. Fair enough. But I won’t be coming back to it any time soon - Lancashire isn’t a lifestyle game for me, so at 6-7 plays a year I expect I have years of play before it starts to get stale. I doubt Birmingham sees the table again in that time.

I've never played any Brass game, and while I would have rather played OG Brass first, I did take advantage of an open seat at a table of the current rankings leader for this site. Much of this game is what I would have expected from a Martin Wallace game: two actions per turn, punishing economy, and precise theme. I'm going to preface the rest of this with a few contextual caveats. First, this is a first impression after a single play. Second, I don't think our teach was particularly good, which I've noticed before from this person (who is otherwise perfectly nice). And third, I did terribly. So with that understood, I really didn't care for the game. I definitely understood what the puzzle was supposed to be, especially with how you could set up select infrastructure during the canal phase to best maximize income and victory in the rail phase. I understood how the shared infrastructure could be a blessing and a curse all at once. And I understood how there was a tight scarcity for resources that could sometimes be mitigated through planning and a dash of luck. But I was just miserable the entire time. The restrictions provided by the game weren't interesting for me. The economy was both brutal and brittle, and didn't really allow for a change to recover from early mistakes. A lack of recovery usually isn't a problem for me, but when your game is decided in the first hour of a three hour game, there's not much to say for the game. A game this brutal needs either guardrails, brevity, or dedication; none of those are really available for a pickup game at a weeknight meetup. I definitely will play this again, since even just this bad experience was enough to show me how to have a better time next time. But my overall impression of the game is that it's probably really fun for people who want to play it a lot, and I don't think I'm there.

Have real mixed views on this game. I only own four other economic games and this one would be the lowest rated of the five. Venetia, John Company, Infamous traffic and the Dutch Golden age were far more engaging games on compelling topics. Their components were about equal to this game in quality. This games rules were abit fiddly and required constant review. The theme was unique and building a serious of interconnected industries has its merits in terms of game play. It kept my interest to a degree but it also at times felt like a tedious affair that often became repetitive. You build coal plants, then an ironworks and connected them to a network. Then you build factories and attempt to sell them , but wait you need beer to do so. After a few rounds I started to think is this it? Why is this game rated number one? It is OK but number one? So overall I was not that impressed with this one. I have rated close to 650 games here on bgg and have been playing mainly wargames for 45 years and found this one to be one that was costly and from a cost benefit viewpoint expensive. Compare it to John Company on the east India companies economic take over of India. Much more involved, better historical theme and far more player interaction. Far better value when you consider the amount of playing time you get out of John Bull.

There is a steep learning curve and difficulty wall. The game itself is easy to teach, but the strategy is deep. Shared network building - the player interactions with using each other's networks and resources also comes into play. It can be quite merciless with player interaction, knowing when to build industries, link them, and sell goods. It can be quite mean with people cutting each other off, taking spaces, routes, or resources (even if not directly hurting your opponent). A lot of player interaction and reacting to what others are doing. Going to get some more plays in to see if it's the right fit for me.

A good game, but it's not a 10/10. The game can be both tactical and, for players who know it well, strategic. There is little randomness, a little resulting from the cards, but it's not DB, so the cards are equal and concern what and where we build, which we have a big influence on. During the game, there are so many variables resulting from the expansion of cities that it can't be called repetitive. However, there are a few things that irritate, e.g.: destroying canals and first-level buildings. I know what it's for, what you can do with it, how to use it, why it's mechanical, but I don't really like that halfway through the game, we start it from the beginning. The rules are also a bit pieced together, sometimes resources teleport to us, e.g. beer, other times we have to have a network of connections to deceive them. Mechanically, it works well, we have different resources, we use them differently, you can be more creative, but when it comes to consistency and remembering the rules, it's so ehhhhh, weak. I will play, I won't refuse, I will propose, but I know games that I like more and are more consistent mechanically and atmospherically, where the rules are more fluid.
It's a good, clean game. Works well at two players. The only differences in replay are the random cards you get. We'll keep it and probably play again, but it doesn't amaze us.

I am not very good at this game yet always play with high-skill players, so in this version I can play more competitively and keep better pace with them than in the original version where they crush me with their superior intellects.

I'm not too keen on simulations. Played this with a friend who acquired it and it took us about 2.5 hours to set up and get the rules straight. Then we played a round. In the end we got for most stuff how it works (although I think the rule book is far from good, some contradictions and not linear), but I can see how people like the game. The mechanics are good, and the economical constraints are well modeled, the look & feel is okay, there is a lot of variety, and players have a lot of freedom when developing, i.e. to follow an own strategy. Certainly a game that requires many plays to get the most out of it. Requires concentration and - as mentioned - has quite a steep learning curve. I will play again when asked, but would not suggest it, except for persons who really are into economical simulation games.

The strength that this game has synergy type of environment building atmosphere, where one person to can provide raw materials for another person to use to craft a product while both players score points. Other optional stuff is buiding networks in manufacturing routes, or importing materials at a higher cost from outside the game map, or refining your factories to make more of the same stuff. There is also optional to use "loans" to gain some quick money at a cost, but it's a risky action to take... the risk can either be "expert" move or a huge mistake. This game is long, and has a "medium" level of replayability. I would say there is alot of combinations of future gameplay with "experienced" players but love this type of theme and like refining their strategy, but for me it will get really boring when you play it way too many times. There is no flavor text or events, or whatever. It's hard to believe that is the #1 game for overal rank and strategy. There is way more replayability in other games like Twilight Struggle, Gloomhaven, or Pandemic Legacy. They also has more theme and look ALOT nicer. This game seems way too long

Respectfully, BGG, y'all need to calm down about this game, haha. Was excited to play it because it's been #1 for so long; it was a pretty lengthy teach, which had some of our players struggling to focus. I like the overall theme a lot, and the mechanic of drawing/discarding location cards to take actions, but it was just too heavy for me to see our group tabling it with anything resembling regularity.

There is a place for this game. It's a super crunchy euro with opportunities for fantastic long-term play and varied strategies derived from an interconnected network of resource management and card play... and hoo, boy, did it not work for our game group. They just couldn't wrap their heads around just about any element, and even trying again just at two, it felt like there was a LOT to keep track of. Unlike something like Ark Nova or Endless Winter, the art and theme didn't suck us in, so it just felt crunchy and a bit too much like work for us. I can definitely see the appeal of the game, and I'd honestly play it again, and happily... but it's not one we need to own, and isn't one we'd table regularly if we did. (And I genuinely don't see how this is the highest rated BGG entry, but what can you do.)

It is a good game on a unique topic. Who knew that the Industrial Revolution could be such a great topic to game. Overall as a gaming experience I found it interesting. You take on the role of a industrialist who builds an industrial empire. The mechanics have a unique historical flair but are abit fiddly on your first game. A crunchy and smooth euro. Certainly a bit heavy, but the game is a blast to play. I really need to play this one more. This game is another proof that hand-management is the best mechanism in gaming. The current king of BGG, it's definitely one of the best euros that I've ever played. The set up is a bit long, but it's all worth it. All the mechanics of the game shines through, and it's very engaging and fun to construct new "buildings" and deliver goods. And the beautiful artwork is just the cherry on top.

That being said, it does still feel a bit dry and less exciting compared to lots of other heavy euro games that I love. I personally enjoy A Feast for Odin, Kanban EV, and Great Western Trail a lot more. Maybe because the currency and numbers in those games are smaller and less math-y.

This is a very interactive game: players must look for ways to interfere with their opponents’ plans by blocking access to markets and resources. While that’s going on, you must somehow implement a plan of your own while factoring in all the ways your opponents could mess it up. The result is a fascinating but often frustrating game.

The art and graphics are too dark, even on the “daylight” side of the double sided board. This is too bad because the art is excellent. The dark shading is meant to be thematic by portraying the dirty coal smoke pollution of the period. It’s as if a dark grey filter is overlaid on the board but it’s so dark it's difficult to discern the features necessary for play without bright room lighting.

Brass: Brimingham est un très bon jeu, mais ce n'est pas non plus le meilleur jeu de tous les temps. Il est probable que son évaluation bénéficie d'un biais de conformisme, c'est le numéro 1 sur BBG donc il devient nécessairement excellent. Mais personnellement, je ne le qualifierais que de très bon, il ne suscite pas en moi l'excitation qui rend certains jeux exceptionnels.

De la même façon sa note de poids est grandement surévaluée, je m'explique : comme il est numéro 1, il attire un public curieux peu habitué aux jeux experts et comme c'est un excellent jeu d'introduction à ceux-là, il peut apparaître lourd et complexe à un public non averti. Mais en soi, les mécaniques du jeu sont simple et les actions très faciles à assimiler avec des stratégies plutôt commodes à mettre en place et lisibles. Il est assez facile de savoir ce que poursuit un adversaire. Reste alors à évaluer s'il est plus intéressant d'interférer avec son projet d'action ou plutôt de se concentrer sur sa propre stratégie, ou mieux encore de parvenir à faire les deux à la fois. Mais globalement le jeu reste d'une difficulté plutôt moyenne et même assez accessible (un nouveau joueur ne sera pas perdu comme devant un Dune ou un Narak).

Une partie prendra deux à trois heures selon l'expérience des joueurs et leur rapidité d'exécution. La séparation en deux périodes avec une réinitialisation presque complète, à l'exception de quelques bâtiments de niveau II ou III est assez intéressante. Autre intérêt du jeu, on est rarement bloqué, avec un chemin d'action assez variées (tout en restant simples et aisées à prendre en main). Cependant, si un déséquilibre se fait, il sera malgré tout assez complexe à endiguer et parfois le vainqueur est connu six ou sept actions avant la fin.

Bref, un bilan globalement très positif, mais sans doute pas à la hauteur des promesses suscitées par ses notes et sa hype.

+Incredible depth of strategy. Brain burning turns trying to figure out what, where and in which order to build.
+The player economy and heavy interaction is a joy. "Helping" other players out by flipping their tiles makes everyone feel good, but can quickly swing to tense denial as someone takes your last beer. Need to always be on your toes to see how changes in the board state benefits or harms you.
+Lots of opportunities to feel clever in short-term tactics to take advantage of board/market state, and also longer-term planning for big sales.

-Easily creates AP in players, making the game drag at 4p.
-Takes a couple plays to really see the tactics and strategies. First play is mostly just figuring out WHAT you can do with your cards.

≈The cards act as a limit to what you're able to do, which is not my preference for a heavy strategy game. The "do the best with what you've been given" feels more tactical. Contrast this with Terra Mystica where all the actions are available to you, but it is your resources that limit your choices.
≈Strategizing and playing well is a massive brain burn. It's a lot of work just figuring out what the cards allow you to do, before you can even work out an optimal strategy from the available options.

Gave it a shot to see what all the hype was about, and I was pleasantly surprised! The economic choices are varied. Stealing resources from others, or getting your resources stolen, does not feel too cutthroat since you get hefty benefits from depleting resources, no matter who was responsible for this. This makes these "take that" choices feel less malevolent and the less obvious choice to take, because you need to think about whether it helps them more than it helps you. It's also surprisingly not a super long game unless you have players with bad cases of AP. The setup is a bit tedious, but I always measure games by the setup/fun ratio, and the fun in this case is worth it.

What a cool game. The aesthetic is great, the strategy runs deep, and I absolutely adore the interconnectedness of the economy. Seeing this level of interaction in a Euro is so refreshing. The players have immense agency over the state of the game, and the way it all comes together is magical.

That said, some of the rules are incredibly unintuitive, bordering on arcane (iron can teleport, coal cannot, beer can for you, etc). There's enough weirdness to make it genuinely difficult to explain with a straight face. It's not particularly complex in the traditional sense; there's not that many actions you can take, but these strange caveats combined with the obtuse nature of how to actually play the game well makes for a large barrier to entry. I also find the game can veer into being slightly dry after many plays.

Still, this is an amazing design. My only real critiques are in regards to the teach, and once players learn it this is a masterpiece. The fact that this game allows for this level of enmeshment between the players is a breath of fresh air, and something I must find more of.
